Executive Summary

Albemarle Pasadena Risk Management Plan - 2014 Resubmission



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The Albemarle Pasadena facility is committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and responsible manner so as to protect employees, the community, and the environment.  As a corporation, Albemarle has committed to following the American Chemistry Council's Responsible Care® program, including the Process Safety Code.  Albemarle Corporation's 2014 Health, Safety, Security and Environmental Policy states, in part:



We will take personal responsibility for safety and are committed to ensuring that we cause no harm to ourselves, our co-workers or the communities in which we operate. Our goal is to maintain an incident-free, secure and healthy workspace.  Working in a safe, secure and environmentally responsible manner is an inherent part of our jobs and a condition of employment for each of us. We will comply with all applicable legal requirements and company policies and procedures. Our commitment is deep and serious: Any employee, whether salary or wage, who violates safety, process safety, environmental or security policies and procedures at any time, or commits an unsafe act, whether there is a resulting incident or not, will be subject to disciplinary action up to and including termination. Each of us will take appropriate steps, including discontinuing operations if necessary, to correct actions and conditions before they lead to incidents, and no one will undertake any task unless it can be done in a safe and environmentally responsible manner.  We adhere to the principles and expectations of Responsible Care® in our daily operations.



The Albemarle Pasadena facility has a robust commitment to emergency response, coordinating site-wide emergency response teams with our site partners, Houston Ship Channel industry neighbors, and local authorities.

 



Facility and Regulated Su

bstances



The Albemarle Pasadena plant produces a variety of organic industrial chemicals that are sold and transported around the world.  The primary product group at the plant is a family of chemicals known as organometallics.  The primary use of these chemicals is as a catalyst in the plastics and other industries.  Some of the organometallics are also used on-site in the production of other specialty organic chemicals, including industrial intermediates, agricultural chemicals, and curatives.  Albemarle Pasadena shares its site with three partner companies.



Per ?68.130, there are six chemicals regulated under the EPA Risk Management Program that are present above the threshold quantity at the Albemarle Pasadena site.  Listed toxic chemicals are chlorine and methyl chloride.  Listed flammable chemicals are 1-butene, ethyl chloride, 2-methyl propene (isobutylene), and isopentane.  Anhydrous hydrogen chloride, ethylene, and hydrogen are used on the plant site, but in quantities below the regulatory threshold.



Regardless of regulatory listing or quantity, Albemarle Pasadena manages all site processes and equipment as if they were covered by the OSHA PSM or EPA RMP standards.  Our release prevention plan and contingency planning programs are tools that we use to manage the potential hazards posed by these chemicals to our employees, the public and the environment.





General Accidental Release Prevention Program



Albemarle Corporation has always believed in taking a structured, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of chemicals.  The most significant management system in place is the Process Safety Management Program, which is designed to comply with and exceed the requirements set forth by OSHA in 29 CFR 1910.119.



The Albemarle Pasadena site has implemented an aggressive mechanical integrity and inspection program to identify and correct potential problems before they occur.  Employees are empowered and encouraged to identify anything o

ut of the ordinary and take corrective action.  Processes are routinely evaluated for hazards, and corrective actions are implemented in accordance with generally accepted good engineering practices.



Processes are operated and controlled with a computer-based distributive control system which is programmed to alert operators of abnormal conditions and take corrective action when safety limits are threatened.



 

Chemical-specific Prevention Steps



The site has implemented the following chemical-specific prevention steps:



Chlorine:

- Area monitors are installed near the treatment station to alert operators of any release.  

- Only two of four cylinders are connected to the process at any one time.



Methyl Chloride:

- Methyl chloride is inventoried only when it is to be used in the production process, limiting the time at risk.

- Area detectors are installed at the methyl chloride unloading station to alert operators of any release.

- The storage vessel area is equipped with a deluge system.



1-Butene:

- The storage vessels are equipped with a deluge system.

- Area detectors are installed at the unloading and transfer areas to alert operators of any release.



Ethyl Chloride:

- The storage vessel is equipped with a deluge system.

- The storage vessel is insulated to minimize fire exposure.

- The vessel is placed within a dike.



2-Methyl Propene (Isobutylene):

- The storage vessel is equipped with a deluge system.

- Area detectors are installed at the unloading and transfer areas to alert operators of any release.



Isopentane:

- The process vessels are equipped with deluge systems or other fire-fighting equipment.

- The vessel is insulated to minimize fire exposure.

- The vessel is equipped with a dike.





Five-Year Accident History



The Albemarle Pasadena plant maintains an active computer-based incident, investigation, and corrective action database.  A search of our incident data base confirmed that there have been no acci

dental releases from covered processes with significant impact per ?68.42 during this five-year period from June 2009 to June 2014.



 

Emergency Response Program



The Albemarle Pasadena plant maintains a contingency plan which consolidates all federal, state and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  The plant program provides the essential planning and training to effectively protect workers, emergency responders, the public and the environment during an emergency.  Our emergency response plan is coordinated with that of the community, the Pasadena LEPC, the Channel Industries Mutual Aid Association (CIMA) and industrial neighbors who share our fence line (SunEdison, Ethyl and Enterprise).  This shared fence line defines our chemical complex.



The site emergency response team (ERT) is composed of members from all companies operating on the complex.  The ERT consist of  four sections that include the fire brigade, the haz-mat team, the rescue team and the emergency medical team.  All team members are trained to the hazardous materials technician level, which allows them to not only respond to fires, but also spills of hazardous material.  To assure that the ERT is ready for any complex emergency, frequent drills are held with our industrial neighbors on the complex.  In addition, the ERT also participates in the local mutual aid (CIMA) drills.  Drills are also used to evaluate the ability of complex personnel to understand and operate under the emergency plan.  In addition to our emergency personnel, our emergency response has a fully equipped ambulance, two fire trucks, a rescue vehicle and a haz-mat truck.  In addition to complex emergencies, these vehicles are also available to the Channel Industries Mutual Aid Association for off-plant responses.



Albemarle has the responsibility for maintaining the mobile emergency response equipment and for training of the members of the ERT.





Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Con

tinuous improvement of safety performance is part of Albemarle Pasadena's operating philosophy.  This is handled through the PHA program, hazard recognitions, and other efforts.  Some current efforts include:



- Layer of protection analyses are being applied to all covered processes to ensure that all safeguards are independent and adequate to prevent a catastrophic release.



- Ventilation systems are being installed in a set of reactor cubicles to reduce the likelihood of an accumulation of flammable vapors due to a significant release



- Safety instrumented systems are being designed and improved for a set of reactors.
